body.p: To His Excellency Thomas E Bramlet, Governor of Kentucky.

Your Petitioner Ben S Griffin would respectfully represent to you that William Swincher was held to bail by the Judge of the Police Court for the City of Louisville, to answer for a felony. at the September term of the Jefferson Circuit Court 1865 in the sum of three hundred dollars. and security in the like amount.

Your petitioner was induced by the constant importunities of the mother of said Swincher, (an aged and infirm widow who was mainly dependent upon him her said sons labor for support) to become bail for him (said Wm Swincher) for his appearance at the September term of the Court aforesaid, at the term aforesaid.

Your petitioner being well acquainted with the family of said Swincher, and assured by them that said William Swincher would appear in said Court at the term aforesaid, acted in the premises through charitable motives alone in becoming Bail aforesaid.

At the seting of the Court aforesaid in September 1865 as aforesaid the said William Swincher failed to appear to answer. -- a forfeiture of said Bond was therefore taken and your petitioner made liable therefor. A Judgment was at the last term of said Court rendered against your petitioner for three hundred dollars, the amount of said Bond.

Your petitioner is man upwards of sixty years old, and a Cripple, -- makes his living by labor as a Carpenter, and if Compelled to pay the amount of aforesaid will be seriously injured. He therefore in view of the forgoing facts, Prays your Excellency to exorcise the Clemency pertaining
to your perogative, by remetting all that portion of said forfeiture and Judgment you have the power to remit, and your petitioner will ever pray &

B S Griffin
William G. Reasor
attorney for the City of Louisville Ky
Jos. Clement Justice of the peace Jeff Co Ky
James Harris
W F Barret
Will, P, Thomasson
Sam Matlock. J. P. J. C
C. Ripley
W. R. Thompson
I do not Know any thing the facts stated, except that Mr Griffin is a lame man who lives by his work, and is not as well off as he once was. I shall be glad if he can be let off.

Henry Pirtle
J. B Gaither att
A V Walker
Philip Tomppert Mayor

Jefferson Cir Ct
vs
Ben S. Griffin
